Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the step-parent needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation2: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Story: I was in the supermarket with my stepson, trying to keep an eye on him while mentally running through the checklist of tasks I needed to finish for work. My phone buzzed with a reminder: the report for the team was due in two hours, and I still had a few sections left to polish. I glanced up just in time to see my stepson darting between aisles, giggling as he narrowly missed bumping into an elderly woman. I felt the weight of my responsibility as a step-parent—this was a moment to teach him about respect and discipline, to guide him gently but firmly. But my mind was also with my colleagues, knowing that if I didn’t submit my part on time, the whole project would stall and my teammate would be left waiting. I could feel the tension building inside me, torn between stepping in to correct my stepson’s behavior and finding a quiet corner to finish my work. Both roles demanded my full attention, and I stood there, heart pounding, caught between what I owed my family and what I owed my team.
